Name: Constitution
Summary:
The supreme law of the United States of America, the Constitution delineates the framework for the federal government, including the doctrine of Separation of Powers. The Constitution has 7 Articles:
  • Article I: Creates a Congress made up of a Senate and House of Representatives. Grants Congress legislative power.
  • Article II: Creates the offices of President and Vice President. Grants the president specific executive powers.
  • Article III: Establishes the Judicial Branch and grants the Judiciary jurisdiction.
  • Article IV: Details the states rights and obligations between each other and with respect to the federal government.
  • Article V: Provides the procedure to amend the Constitution.
  • Articles VI: Declares the Constitution to be the supreme law of the United States
  • Article VII: Establishes the procedure for ratifying the Constitution.

Name: Bill of Rights
Summary:
The Bill of Rights are the first 10 amendments to the Constitution. The amendments were ratified just two years after the ratification of the Consitution in response to concerns regarding Constitutional protection of individual freedoms. The Bill of Rights includes many specific limitations on governmental power.

It was written by James Madison, who was strongly influenced by the Virginia Declaration of Rights written by George Mason.

Name: 11th Amendment
Summary: Makes states immune from suits from out-of-state citizens and foreigners not living within the state borders; lays the foundation for sovereign immunity.

Name: 12th Amendment
Summary: Revises Presidential election procedures, namely that the Vice-President will be a separate electable position than President. This opens the door to running mates.

Name: 14th Amendment
Summary: Defines citizenship, limits the individual states' powers with respect to citizens via the Privileges or Immunities Clause, the Due Process Clause, the Equal Protection Clause.

Name: 15th Amendment
Summary: Prohibits the denial of the right to vote based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude.

Name: 16th Amendment
Summary: Gives Congress power to levy an income tax.

Name: 17th Amendment
Summary: Establishes the direct election of United States Senators by popular vote.  Under Article I of the Constitution, members of the state legislatures had previously chosen United States Senators.

Name: 18th Amendment
Summary: Prohibits the manufacture, transport, or sale of alcohol within the United States.

Name: 19th Amendment
Summary: Prohibits the denial of the right to vote based on sex.

Name: 20th Amendment
Summary: Changes the date on which the terms of the President and Vice President (January 20) and Senators and Representatives (January 3) end and begin.

Name: 23rd Amendment
Summary: Grants the District of Columbia electors in the Electoral College.

Name: 24th Amendment
Summary: Prohibits the denial of the right to vote due to the non-payment of taxes.

Name: 25th Amendment
Summary: Provides Presidential and Vice-Presidential succession procedures.

Name: 26th Amendment
Summary: Prohibits the denial of the right to vote of citizens, eighteen years of age or older, on account of age.

Name: 27th Amendment
Summary: Delays laws affecting Congressional salary from taking effect until after the next election of representatives.
